mentions.context: MTG-Link integrates another assembly algorithm: the Iterative Read Overlap algorithm.
MTG-Link is freely available at https: // github.
MTG-Link parameters MTG-Link was used in version 1.1.0
MTG-Link was used with the DBG algorithm, with a k-mer size of [61,51,41,31,21] and a solid k-mer threshold of [3,2].
MTG-Link was assessed on simulated gaps of various sizes from a real linked read dataset of one H. numata genome.
MTG-Link was run with the DBG algorithm.
MTG-Link is available on GitHub (https://github.com/anne-gcd/MTG-Link)

MindThe-Gap was originally developed for the detection and assembly of insertion variants, but it also includes an efficient local assembly module (fill module) that relies on a De Bruijn graph data structure to represent the input read sequences.
In MTG-link, it is then used to perform a local assembly for each pair of gap-flanking k-mers.
As MTG-Link was run with the DBG algorithm, the local assembly step is the same in both approaches.

In MindTheGap, as in any De Bruijn graph based assembly, two parameters have major impacts on the quality of the assembly: the k-mer size and the k-mer abundance threshold for including a k-mer in the graph (solid k-mer threshold).
Thus, MTG-Link will perform the local assembly between the sequences surrounding the extended gap, e.g. from the k-mer START (source) to the k-mer STOP (target).
Thus, MTG-Link has a precision of 90% with a recall of 75%.
Then, MTG-Link assigns a two-letters quality score to each gap-filled sequence.
Hence, MTG-Link is a time/memory efficient gap-filling tool.
Although MTG-Link tests several parameters values contrary to MindTheGap, it remains faster thanks to the read subsampling step.
We tested MTG-Link on four different gap sizes (1, 5, 10 and 20 Kbp).
We applied MTG-Link to the gap-filling of the Supergene P locus (1.3 Mbp) of the butterfly Heliconius numata.
We applied MTG-Link on real gaps from real linked read datasets to improve the contiguity of the Supergene P locus of the butterfly Heliconius numata.
Importantly, MTG-Link is also significantly faster than MindTheGap.

We also applied MTG-Link on individual genomes of a mimetic butterfly (Heliconius numata), where it significantly improved the contiguity of a 1.3 Mb locus of biological interest.
For the moment, MTG-Link was mainly tested with the DBG algorithm, and we have shown that this algorithm performs well, especially on small gaps.
Additional Python scripts for converting input and output files to the desirable formats are also provided.
For each gap size, MTG-Link and MindTheGap were applied on a set of 57 simulated gaps.
We have shown that MTG-Link outperforms MindTheGap, in terms of both time and gap-filling quality.
The main feature of MTG-Link is that it takes advantage of the linked-read barcode information to get a subsample of reads of interest for the local assembly of each gap.
MTG-Link parameters MTG-Link was used in version 1.1.0
A valuable feature of MTG-Link is to assign a qualitative score to each gap-filled sequence.

In this work, we present MTG-Link, a novel gap-filling tool dedicated to linked read data.
In this work, we present MTG-Link, a novel gap-filling tool for draft genome assemblies dedicated to linked read data.

The quality score assigned by MTG-Link during the qualitative evaluation step does not give a perfect auto-evaluation of the gap-filling, but it still improves its accuracy.
The gap-fillings performed by MTG-Link were compared to those obtained with MindTheGap, the tool used in the local assembly step of our pipeline.
One of the characteristics of MTG-Link is that it can use either a De Bruijn Graph (DBG) algorithm or an Iterative Read Overlap algorithm in the local assembly step.
Alignments are performed with Nucmer [19].
Implementation and availability MTG-Link is written in Python 3. In order to speed up the process, it uses a trivial parallelization scheme by giving each gap to a separate thread.
For each gap size, MTG-Link and MindTheGap were applied on a set of 57 simulated gaps.
As expected, MTG-Link outperforms MindTheGap by returning more successful gap-fillings, for all tested gap sizes.

We showed that the read subsampling step of MTG-Link enables to get better gap assemblies in less CPU time.
Pipeline overview We propose a method, called MTG-Link, that aims at filling gaps in draft genome assemblies using linked read data.
Results are presented in Fig. 2. As expected, MTG-Link outperforms MindTheGap by returning more successful gap-fillings, for all tested gap sizes.
Only 34% of gaps were successfully filled with MindTheGap, against 75% with MTG-Link.

In this work, we provide a novel gap-filling tool for linked read data, called MTG-Link.

Several tools have been developed for local assembly or gap-filling with short read data, such as GapCloser [13], Sealer [14], GapFiller [15], GAPPadder [16] and MindTheGap [17].
We validated our approach on a real 10X genomics dataset, in which gaps were simulated, and compared it to MindTheGap, that does not use the barcode information.
The two approaches differ by the read subsampling and the qualitative evaluation steps which are specific to MTG-Link.

For this purpose, we re-scaffolded this locus by analyzing shared barcodes between scaffolds, and performed gap-filling with MTG-Link.
Several tools have been developed for local assembly or gap-filling with short read data, such as GapCloser [13], Sealer [14], GapFiller [15], GAPPadder [16] and MindTheGap [17].
Both use the same De Bruijn Graph assembly algorithm, allowing to assess the benefit of the additional read subsampling step of MTG-Link prior to local assembly.
For each gap, it extracts the linked reads whose barcode is observed in chunk regions surrounding the gap, using the thirdparty tool LRez [18].
More precisely, we observed that the gaps labelled as "no gap-fillings" but having a number of barcodes higher than 500 are those for which MTG-Link finds a solution but with a bad quality score.

We validated our approach on a real 10X genomics linked read dataset, on a set of simulated gaps, and showed that the read subsampling step of MTG-Link enables to get better gap assemblies in a time/memory efficient manner.
Several tools have been developed for local assembly or gap-filling with short read data, such as GapCloser [13], Sealer [14], GapFiller [15], GAPPadder [16] and MindTheGap [17].
Twelve individuals genomes with different haplotypes were sequenced with the 10X Genomics Chromium technology and were assembled in draft genome with the Supernova assembler [20].

Comparison with other approaches To assess the impact of the read subsampling on the quality of the gap-filling, the running time and the memory consumption, we compared the results obtained with MTG-Link to those obtained with MindTheGap.
